text.front:
PHOTOLUMINESCENCE DYNAMICS OF SPACER LAYER
CARRIERS IN MULTI STACKED QUANTUM DOTS
O. Kojima 1,* T. Kita 1 , and K. Akahane 2
1 Department of Electric and Electronic Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Kobe University, 1-1
Rokkodai, Nada, Kobe 657-8501, Japan
2 National Institute of Information and Communications Technology, 4-2-1 Nukui-kitamachi, Koganei, Tokyo
184-8795, Japan
text.p:
Stacked quantum dots (QDs) have immense potential for many technological applications, such as the
next generation optoelectronic devices. Recently, we have reported advantages of the multi-stacked QDs
fabricated using the strain-compensation technique [1-3] to design the optical properties through the excitonic
characteristics and to fabricate the high-quality and high-density QD ensemble [4-6]. For the application of the
stacked QD ensemble to the optical devices, the clarification and manipulation of the intraband relaxation
processes of electrons and holes are required. The stacked QD ensemble consists of the QD layers and the
spacer layers which compensate the strain caused by the lattice mismatch. Therefore, the clarification of the
relation between dynamics of the excitons in the QDs and the carriers in the spacer layers will play a key role to
improve the device performance. In the present work, we focus on the correlation between carriers generated in
the spacer layers and the QDs.
We used a sample of InAs self-assembled QDs with 30
layers were grown on an InP(311)B substrate by molecular
beam epitaxy using a strain compensation technique. The sample
has In 0.5 Ga 0.1 Al 0.4 As spacer layers with the thickness of 20 nm. The
QD density in each layer is 3.4 x 10 10 /cm 2 . According to our
previous report [5], the QDs are interconnected along the growth
direction. The spacer layer compensates for the stress caused by the
lattice mismatch between the QD layer and the buffer layer. The PL
decay profiles were measured with streak camera system with a
time resolution of 40 ps. The excitation source was a mode-locked
Ti:sapphire pulse laser delivering about 100-fs pulses with a
repetition rate of 80 MHz. The excitation photon energy was 1.55
eV, which is higher than the bandgap energy of the InGaAlAs
spacer layer. Figure 1 indicates the temperature dependence of the
PL decay profile in the energy region of the spacer layer. The PL
decay time increases with an increase in the temperature. In Fig. 2,
the PL decay time plots as a function of the temperature. This
increase is similar to the increase in the PL decay time of QDs
observed in this sample [6]. The carriers generated in the spacer
layers have the two relaxation process; one is the direct PL
relaxation and another one is transfer to the QDs. Therefore, this
increase in the PL decay time results from the suppression of the
carrier transfer from the spacer layers to the QDs.
